body: Please check your py3 compatibility: https://travis-ci.org/dhuang/incubator-airflow
@bolkedebruin why was this reverted? Are we not allowed to commit to master while 1.8.0 release is in flight?
NM, I see--you've reverted from 1.8.0 test branch.

Thanks! Please do add unit tests. You can use mock for this and remove the need for a scrapyd server. There are some examples in the code base. What you are referring is more of the likes of integration tests.

@robin-miller-ow I think this is the wrong approach to make the change. A DAG does not have an execution date, but a DagRun does. A Task does not have an execution_date but a TaskInstance does by inheriting it from the DagRun.

So I would expect:
`/dags/<string:dag_id>/<datetime:execution_date>/tasks/<string:task_id>`

to return the information you are looking for.
LGTM, your issues might stem from not being fully rebase on master.

@Fokko can you please add unit tests?

@jhsenjaliya some standard connection settings could also apply and be set by an admin (such as kerberos details, master etc). Also unit testing is a bit easier with a wrapper like this (we have more of those).
@gsakkis can you please rebase?

@jhsenjaliya I think @artwr was concerned about excessive logging stored via xcom. I understand you are using temp files now but i think for backward compatibility a few things needs to be considered:

1) some people would prefer to retain old behavior when only last like is pushed to XCOM vs. everything
2) I really liked old behavior when I could look at the full output using UI - I think with changed you made, output won't be available via UI unless I am missing something

Overall all the defaults should behave like they do currently while changes you suggested should be all optional. just IMHO

@bolkedebruin That seems inconsistent to me. When I added a date into the tigger dag API, you said it should be sent in the data, not the URL, so I presume we'd still want to do that. If this is not the right URL, then based on the trigger dag URL, would:
`/dags/<string:dag_id>/dag_runs/task_instance/<string:task_id>`
be more consistent? Possibly:
`/dags/<string:dag_id>/dag_runs/<datetime:execution_date>/task_instance/<string:task_id>`
but I would then expect the be posting to
`/dags/<string:dag_id>/dag_runs/<datetime:execution_date>`
to create a dag run at a specific time. Thoughts?
@robin-miller-ow that is actually unrelated: GET vs POST. So no that is not more consistent
Lgtm
@jlowin thanks!
thanks @bolkedebruin!
Looks like one travis failure during installation (30 seconds in) but the others are proceeding and are passing in my branch (https://travis-ci.org/jlowin/airflow/builds/197700341), going to merge.
Airflow 782 is not in 1.8. I reverted that one for 1.8 but you probably excluded reverts :-)
Please don't tag it rc1 but 1.8.0. The rc can become release right away if we find no blockers.
Waiting on #2049 to gain transparency into the Travis errors
@bolkedebruin commit rebased

@artwr @aoen PTAL. Made all suggested changes. 
- Replaced file_format param with input_compressed
- Moved uncompress_file to utils
- Added test cases for uncompress_file
- Removed explicit list cast on self.field_dict.keys()
- Added all mentioned formatting changes

LMK if this looks ok. I will squash the comments and rebase the branch.

@boristyukin, pls find comment inline.  

update : ( rephrasing the same comment )

1. some people would prefer to retain old behavior when only last like is pushed to XCOM vs. everything
-  I think this would be consider a `BUG`, not affecting to one-liner output use-case, it can be user given regex filtered though ( specially if concern is about large output )
- in any case, if user is interested in only getting last line, he/she can use `| tail -1` or can introduce feature in bash_operator `getLastLine()`.

2. I really liked old behavior when I could look at the full output using UI - I think with changed you made, output won't be available via UI unless I am missing something
- sure I will add output to the log.

Thanks for the review

There are some really good ideas here and the code is top notch but I have some concerns with bringing this new complexity in the project. When thinking about "data flow" or "a data driven dependency engine" I think each committer and user might have very different mental model on how this should/could work ideally. For example, my original set of ideas were pretty different, but not better by any mean, just different, and I feel like we should get a good consensus on design before moving forward with a feature this foundational.

In any case, this is a really good way to start the conversation! Here are a few related thoughts:
* your implementation seems more about standardizing how tasks pass data to one another more than about having a data-driven dependency engine (which I think was a key element in the original discussion). The dataflow interface might need a `dataflow_exists(task_instance)` for the scheduler to use, though I have mixed feelings about mixing task and data-dependencies...
* I'm open to the idea of doing something similar to `XComs` for data payload as it can be useful in some cases to pass data across tasks in a standard way, though I'd advise most people to avoid this pattern in most cases since it's assuming data transformations in single-threaded Python in a non-streaming kind of way. Heavy lifting should be done out of Airflow, in Spark or Hive, some MPP database or whatever, but I get the use case for small data, "just glue things together" 
* Could the ideas behind the `Dataflow` abstraction be implemented as an interface that some hooks could implement since hooks already deal with authentication and connectivity to external systems? Say the S3Hook could implement the 3-4 methods and become "Dataflow compliant", meaning you could specify a `dataflow_conn_id` as a target and use a key that's directly related to the task instance
* If the source / sink supports streaming, could set/get be implemented as generators? It's pretty common to want to process an amount of data that may not fit in memory on the worker slot. It's kind of a slippery slope from that point though...
@bolkedebruin I've added unit tests for both the hook and operator. Please let me know if it sufficient.
@bolkedebruin I've finally managed to get this to have Landscape and Travis happy. Are there any further blockers on this being merged?

@aoen Can you create a patch and send it to the mailinglist?

`git format-patch v1-8-stable --stdout -s > cgroup_creation.patch`

It seems a bit cumbersome and might not be the best way to approach this workflow. At the moment it is just a procedural guard against 'just' changing a release. Let's try it and see how it goes. After that (and nobody complains) I'll apply it to the RC. 

I think git should keep history correct and you should be able to apply it yourself against master and v1-8-test . 

Btw I don't think builds will finish properly for master mysql/postgres with py3, I see that with other PRs.
Will do and thanks Bolke (also thanks for heads up re tests)
LGTM +1

Not sure if I should post this here or on the dev mailing list, but since I'm responding to @mistercrunch comments on this PR directly I thought they made more sense here:

I agree with the first point about as implemented Dataflow obscures the relationship between data dependencies and task dependencies in the DAG, as the presence of a Dataflow on a task implicitly sets a task dependency during DAG rendering. I also like the third point about making the IO part of passing data down the DAG tied to the connection hook logic to take advantage of the connection system already built into Airflow. 

I disagree with the second point in the sense that I think there's a number of people (based on hearing from them re: our dataflow-esque workaround fileflow) who primarily want to use Airflow workers as a single threaded data processing system for a pipeline of smaller streaming or non-streaming tasks, my own use case included. For us and possibly for them, the other solutions built more expressly for that purpose were missing a lot in the monitoring and reportability feature space so we couldn't guarantee the SLAs we wanted, but we didn't want to/were not at a data size yet to warrant investing in the heavy lifting technologies like Spark.

Given that, it may become a question of as to what paradigms of workflows Airflow is intending to address, or at least in how standard/batteries-included of a way. If, by way of providing this system to pass data down the DAG, Airflow would be implicitly supporting processing bigger result sets than workers might be provisioned to do, the slippery slope of point four becomes an issue. However since I'm already drinking the kool-aid of doing data processing inside Airflow workers, I'm a fan of building the "dataflow compliant" hooks (or wherever the IO lives) in a way to support streaming IO to protect against worker hardware variability in the wild.

Hi,
you can close this PR. I will not open a jira issue for this nor search for other typos. Too much overhead for everbody.

Looks good and I like that one can use the zdesk client plus you have patched the call method to work through pagination. On that, please note that the way Zendesk's APIs multi-page end-points return responses is different for their Core API and Incremental Export API. For Core, they simply set the next_page to null so that you don't make additional calls (and this is well handled in the zdesk client), for incremental export api, the next_page in the last page of the result set is set to a url which you are supposed to save and start getting the results from that point onwards (next time you run your fetch). You can also use the 'count' value to tally up the number of objects you have gathered so far :)
